content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy B{B} for the following reasons:

1. The payoff structure suggests that my opponent seems to have an advantage when they pick R compared to when I pick R (they get 42$ compared to my 0$). This implies that my opponent might be more likely to choose R.

2. In the long run, choosing B consistently will guarantee a minimum payoff of 12$ per round, whereas picking R will result in losing money for at least half of the rounds (since my opponent's expected choice is R).

3. While there might be an incentive to switch strategies after some rounds to exploit an opponent's pattern, sticking with a consistent strategy like B reduces the risk of being exploited by predictable behavior.

4. In this particular game, the total payoff over 75 rounds matters more than individual round-by-round gains. Given the long term nature of the game, consistently choosing B{B} is the better choice for accumulating a larger payoff overall.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.

I will choose R{R} for the following reasons:

1. In the previous round, I stuck with my strategy of choosing B and so did my opponent, resulting in a lower payoff compared to other possible outcomes (if one player picked R). This suggests that sticking with one strategy might not always maximize my payoffs.

2. Switching strategies can help exploit an opponent's pattern or potentially earn higher payoffs in the long run. In this case, since my opponent chose B last round, it is worth considering whether they will continue to do so or switch strategies.

3. It is possible that my opponent may have been choosing R initially and was waiting for me to switch strategies before doing so themselves. By changing strategies now, I might be able to capitalize on any potential switching behavior from my opponent.

4. Ultimately, the aim of this game is to maximize my payoff over the long term (75 rounds). Changing strategies can help achieve that goal by exploiting patterns in my opponent's choices and earning higher payoffs in some rounds.
